text:
Error signature according to this dialog:
AppName: apache.exe AppVer: 2.0.59.200 ModName: libhttpd.dll
ModVer: 2.0.59.200 Offset: 0013dec

I created two virtual hosts, e.g.
NameVirtualHost *:80

<VirtualHost *>
    
    ServerName lc.blog
    DocumentRoot "C:/.../blog/web"
    
    CustomLog logs/lc.blog.com.access.log combined
    ErrorLog logs/lc.blog.com.error.log
    
</VirtualHost>
<VirtualHost *>
    
    ServerName lc.wiki
    DocumentRoot "C:/.../wiki/web"
    
    CustomLog logs/lc.wiki.access.log combined
    ErrorLog logs/lc.wiki.error.log
    
</VirtualHost>

But somehow only the first one worked, not the second one. I am running Apache
in a VM (VMware Player), will check on a real machine with a working
configuration (1.3) with several virtual hosts.
creator: contact@johnbokma.com
wrowe@apache.org
text:
Your config issue is simple...

NameVirtualHost *:80

<VirtualHost *>

  *:80 != *

ensure they match.  But I'll leave this open since I suspect your point is that
there appears to be a bug in apache -S.

creator: contact@johnbokma.com
text:
Ok, found it :-) Using *:80 instead of just * doesn't trigger this issue. So
with a default install of Apache 2.0.59 on Windows XP, adding to the end of
httpd.conf the following lines:

NameVirtualHost *:80
<VirtualHost *>
</VirtualHost>

will make apache -S halting with an "Needs to close" dialogue

Replacing the * with *:80 doesn't show this behaviour:

NameVirtualHost *:80
<VirtualHost *:80>
</VirtualHost>

And virtual hosts work as expected.

creator: contact@johnbokma.com
text:
"But I'll leave this open since I suspect your point is that
there appears to be a bug in apache -S."

I used * in 1.3 without any problems, which is my bad I guess. (Fixing my
tutorial at the moment,
http://johnbokma.com/windows/apache-virtual-hosts-xp.html, which uses * instead
of *:80). But indeed, apache -S shouldn't die on this.

Apache itself accepts this configuration but it "doesn't work" (no idea if
that's a feature because like you said using * instead of *:80 is wrong).
